name: Campyloneurum atrosquamatum
typeLocations: holotype QCA;isotype AAU;isotype NY 04061672;isotype QCNE;isotype TUR
collectorTeam: R. C. Moran, H. Tuomisto, K. Ruokoleinen & A. Poulsen
distribution: Ecuador (Western South America, Southern America);Acre (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);Amapá (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);Pará (Brazil North, Brazil, Southern America);French Guiana (Northern South America, Southern America);Peru (Western South America, Southern America);
locality: Ecuador. Napo: just outside of Parque Nacional Yasuní, ca. km 26.1 on Maxus Oil Road, transect 18, 300m
remarks: doi:10.1007/s12228-020-09626-9 The specific epithet is a compound of the Latin words 'atro-', dark, and 'squamatum', furnished with scales, referring to the dark-brown, narrow scales that distinguish the species from C. coarctatum.

name: Pleopeltis guttisquamata
distribution: Espírito Santo (Brazil Southeast, Brazil, Southern America)
locality: Nova Venécia, Área de Preservação Ambiental da Pedra do Elefante, afloramento rochoso à direita na subida para a Pedra do Elefante, (300-)600 m
remarks: doi:10.1007/s12228-020-09656-8 The specific epithet means 'with drop-like scales'. It is a compound word combining a noun ('gutta', drop) with an adjective ('squamatus', scaly). It refers to the fact that the leaves have only subulate scales.
